title: Anne Helm
text:
Anne Helm (born September 12, 1938) is a retired Canadian-born actress and children's author (as Annie Helm), who primarily appeared in guest roles on episodes of various American television series. Her few film roles include playing <a href="Elvis%20Presley">Elvis Presley</a>'s love interest in the 1962 film "<a href="Follow%20That%20Dream">Follow That Dream</a>". Helm had two recurring roles, playing Molly Pierce in five episodes during the 85-episode run of the mid-1960s series "<a href="Run%20for%20Your%20Life%20%28TV%20series%29">Run for Your Life</a>" and playing the minor role of nurse Mary Briggs in an unknown number of episodes of the daily soap opera "<a href="General%20Hospital">General Hospital</a>" from 1971 to 1973.
Early years.
Helm was born in Toronto, Canada, and grew up in Ste. Marguerite, a hamlet. Her father was a broker of real estate, and her mother operated a country inn and dairy farm. She began studying ballet with the <a href="National%20Ballet%20Guild%20of%20Canada">National Ballet Guild of Canada</a> when she was 12, and at 14 she studied at the <a href="Metropolitan%20Opera%20Ballet%20School">Metropolitan Opera Ballet School</a>.
Career.
Helm began performing on Broadway in the 1940s as she danced in "High Kickers" (1941), "Lady in the Dark" (1943), and "Mexican Hayride" (1944). 
She returned as an actress, portraying Sally Reece in "Cloud 7" (1958) and Edwina Booth in "Edwin Booth" (1958). During the 1950s, she modeled clothing for teenage girls in New York, made commercials and danced at the Copacabana night club.
Living in New York City, Helm began her pursuit of an acting career, which eventually led to <a href="Hollywood">Hollywood</a>. Beginning in the 1950s, she made guest appearances on <a href="television%20series">television series</a>. Her television debut occurred on "<a href="The%20Phil%20Silvers%20Show">The Phil Silvers Show</a>" in the role of a contestant in a beauty pageant. Her 1958 title role in "<a href="Shirley%20Temple%27s%20Storybook">Shirley Temple's Storybook</a>"'s presentation of "The Sleeping Beauty" was the subject of an article in "<a href="Life%20%28magazine%29">Life</a>" magazine. She made her <a href="motion%20picture">motion picture</a> debut in 1960.
Helm was cast as Linda Moon in the 1960 episode "A Thief or Two" on <a href="CBS">CBS</a>'s <a href="anthology%20series">anthology series</a>, "<a href="The%20DuPont%20Show%20with%20June%20Allyson">The DuPont Show with June Allyson</a>", with co-star <a href="Lew%20Ayres">Lew Ayres</a>. She appeared on the CBS <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">western</a> series "<a href="Rawhide%20%28TV%20series%29">Rawhide</a>" in the episodes "Incident Near Gloomy River (1961) and "Inside Man" (1962). She guest-starred in an episode of the CBS sitcom "<a href="My%20Sister%20Eileen%20%28TV%20series%29">My Sister Eileen</a>", with <a href="Elaine%20Stritch">Elaine Stritch</a> and <a href="Shirley%20Bonne">Shirley Bonne</a>.
In 1961, Helm appeared in an episode of <a href="Alfred%20Hitchcock%20Presents">Alfred Hitchcock Presents</a> ("The Changing Heart", Series 6, episode 14/205, airdate January 3, 1961). She guest-starred in the premiere episode of <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a>'s "<a href="Bus%20Stop%20%28TV%20series%29">Bus Stop</a>" drama series. That same year, she appeared in the first season of CBS's "<a href="Route%2066%20%28TV%20series%29">Route 66</a>" in the episode "The Clover Throne", and in the <a href="Television%20syndication">syndicated</a> <a href="crime%20drama">crime drama</a> "<a href="The%20Brothers%20Brannagan">The Brothers Brannagan</a>" in the episode "Equinox." She also played Glamis Barlow, the title character, in the "<a href="Perry%20Mason%20%281957%20TV%20series%29">Perry Mason</a>" TV episode, "The Case of the Duplicate Daughter."
Helm was cast as Jennie Metcalf, the daughter of an outlaw who seeks vengeance for her father's death, in the 1962 episode "Girl with a Gun", on the <a href="Television%20syndication">syndicated</a> <a href="anthology%20series">anthology series</a>, "<a href="Death%20Valley%20Days">Death Valley Days</a>."
Helm drew national recognition as Holly Jones, the love interest of <a href="Elvis%20Presley">Elvis Presley</a> in his 1962 film "<a href="Follow%20That%20Dream">Follow That Dream</a>". She made five more films during the 1960s including "<a href="The%20Iron%20Maiden">The Iron Maiden</a>" (released in the US as "Swinging Maiden"), a 1962 British made comedy film, "<a href="The%20Interns%20%28film%29">The Interns</a>" (1962), "<a href="Honeymoon%20Hotel%20%281964%20film%29">Honeymoon Hotel</a>" (1964), "<a href="The%20Unkissed%20Bride">The Unkissed Bride</a>" (1966), and the horror film "<a href="Nightmare%20in%20Wax">Nightmare in Wax</a>" (1969).
Helm played different roles in three appearances on "<a href="Wagon%20Train">Wagon Train</a>", an American <a href="western%20%28genre%29">Western</a> series. The first episode Helm was on was entitled "The Dick Pederson Story" (10 Jan. 1962); the second episode was entitled "Heather and Hamish" (10 Apr. 1963) and the third was "The Story of Cain" (16 Dec. 1963).
On January 15, 1963, Helm guest-starred in the episode "Protective Custody" of <a href="NBC">NBC</a>'s "<a href="Laramie%20%28TV%20series%29">Laramie</a>" <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">western</a> series. <a href="David%20Brian">David Brian</a> played Walt Douglas, an official of the stage line, who arrives in <a href="Laramie%2C%20Wyoming">Laramie</a> seeking his estranged daughter, Alicia, portrayed by Helm.
In the "<a href="Gunsmoke">Gunsmoke</a>" TV Series she played "Helena Dales" in "One Killer on Ice", and "Trudy Trent" in "Bad Seed".
Later in 1963, she was cast as Joanie in the series finale, "The Convention," of the modern western series, "<a href="Empire%20%281962%20TV%20series%29">Empire</a>".
In 1963 she also guest-starred as Janie in Season-three of CBS's TV Series "Route 66" in the episode: "Narcissus On An Old Red Fire Engine".
Helm appeared in "<a href="The%20Magic%20Sword%20%281962%20film%29">The Magic Sword</a>" (1962) opposite Basil Rathbone and Gary Lockwood. She was originally cast to play Joan Crawford's daughter Carol in William Castle's "<a href="Strait-Jacket">Strait-Jacket</a>" (1964) but was replaced.
Helm appeared as Nora Martin in a 1964 episode of "<a href="The%20Fugitive%20%281963%20TV%20series%29">The Fugitive</a>" titled "Ballad for a Ghost", and again in a 1964 episode of 'Burke's Law' - 'Who Killed 1/2 Of Glory Lee?' - as Sable Delacroix.
Helm had the role of Amy in the ABC drama "<a href="The%20Long%2C%20Hot%20Summer%20%28TV%20series%29">The Long, Hot Summer</a>" (1965-1966). She also appeared in two episodes of the ABC western series "<a href="The%20Big%20Valley">The Big Valley</a>", both times in a role that interacted prominently with main cast member <a href="Lee%20Majors">Lee Majors</a>. Her first appearance was on October 20, 1965, in the first-season episode "Heritage" in the role of Brydie Hanrahan. Helm then returned on March 4, 1968, in the third season in the episode entitled "The Devil's Masquerade," playing the role of Nancy.
In 1967 she appeared as Jeanne Springer in Season 3 Episode 16 "Long Time Dead" of "<a href="Twelve%20O%27Clock%20High%20%28TV%20series%29">Twelve O'Clock High</a>".
Helms' appearance on "<a href="The%20F.B.I.%20%28TV%20series%29">The F.B.I.</a>" in 1968 was her third on that series in three years. In 1968, Helm appeared as Irene Park in Season 1 of "<a href="Hawaii%20Five-O%20%281968%20TV%20series%29">Hawaii Five-O</a>".
In 1969 she appeared as Karen Mallory on the TV Series "<a href="The%20Virginian%20%28TV%20series%29">The Virginian</a>" in the episode titled "Journey to Scathelock."
From 1971 to 1973, Helm was a regular cast member on the ABC <a href="soap%20opera">soap opera</a> "<a href="General%20Hospital">General Hospital</a>".
In 1986, Helm appeared in the episode "<a href="Amazing%20Stories%20%281985%20TV%20series%29%23ep22">The Doll</a>", on <a href="Steven%20Spielberg">Steven Spielberg</a>'s dramatic television anthology, "<a href="Amazing%20Stories%20%281985%20TV%20series%29">Amazing Stories</a>".
Author.
After her acting career ended in 1986, Helm started writing children's books, as Annie Helm. Her book "The Sunshine Angel Book for Angel Workers of All Ages" was published in 1992, followed in 1993 by "The Little Angel Workbook for Children of all Ages". Fifteen years later, in 2018, her book "Babystar" was published.
Personal life.
Anne Helm was married from 1968 to 1969 to author John Sherlock, with whom she had a son, Peter Sherlock. Her second husband was actor <a href="Robert%20Viharo">Robert Viharo</a>, whom she wed in 1971 and had a daughter, Serena Viharo (born 1977), who also became an actress. Helm and Viharo divorced in 1979.
